65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:09): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I don't think there will be another publication before LCWD, unless that gets dragged out
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:10): which reminds me that I should raise the topic of CR exit criteria
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:10): maybe it would be good to write those before 1st LC
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:18): wonders if "CR exit criteria" are "criteria for reaching CR" or "criteria for reaching PR"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:18): traditionally CR exit criteria are the criteria to exit CR
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:18): the spec is supposed to fulfill them to exit CR
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:19): usually it's something about test suite, implementations, yada yada
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:19): PR entrance criteria
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:19): however I believe the spec has to contain (as opposed to fulfill) them before entering CR
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:19): The process document doesn't really talk about exit criteria afaict
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:27): it seems we do need to prepare a list of "at risk" features
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:28): and a "a report of present and expected implementations"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:28): Also PR entrance criteria include:

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:29): 2. Shown that each feature of the technical report has been implemented. Preferably, the Working Group should be able to demonstrate two interoperable implementations of each feature. If the Director believes that immediate Advisory Committee review is critical to the success of a technical report, the Director may accept to Call for Review of a Proposed Recommendation even without adequate implementation experience;

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:29): 3. Satisfied any other announced entrance criteria (e.g., any included in the request to advance to Candidate Recommendation, or announced at Last Call if the Working Group does not intend to issue a Call for Implementations).
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:29): #3 is presumably what is often called CR exit criteria but which in the Process document are PR entrance criteria

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:31): CSS specs seem to say "Candidate Recommendation Exit Criteria" but then "For this specification to enter Proposed Recommendation, the following conditions must be met:"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:31): so it does seem to be a Process thing, though any requirement beyond the general one about interoperable implementations of each feature seems to be optional
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:31): That one is strictly optional too
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:32): Since it starts "preferably"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:32): It seems like a good idea however
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:33): Or, rather, the other option there seems irrelevent
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:35): So CSS required two complete interoperable implementaions, not two per feature.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:35): hmm, I was going to site the Selectors API CR exit criteria
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:35): which I believe are like the CSS ones
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:35): but they are not in the spec
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:36): I like "two complete interoperable implementations" personally, even though for HTML5 that is a tall order
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:36): but it might be that the test suite is the hard part
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (12:38): have we got any tests from selling t-shirts yet?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:39): I like it in principle, but I think it could create a lot of negative pressure at the end to cut features or make worse tests
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:39): At the moment we don't even knoww what a complete implementation would look like
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:40): I think every feature that doesn't yet have at least one reasonable implementation (maybe any that doesn't have two) should be marked "at risk"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:40): then future generations can make the tradeoff between finalizing HTML5 faster vs having more things in HTML5 rather than deferred to 5.1/6/whatever
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:40): That seems fair
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:41): But I think there will be a lot of perfectly reasonable implementations of things that don't quite pass the testsuite
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:41): If the testsuite is any good
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:41): Which it is mostly not so far
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:41): this is why I think the test suite may be the hard part
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:42): I fully agree that the testsuite will be the hard part
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:42): I don't even know how to reasonably express test suite adequacy in the exit criteria
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:42): I wonder how thorough something like the JCK is compared to the standard we might want for the HTML5 test suite
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:42): Well ideally I would like to have some metric for spec coverage
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:42): Like percentage of assertions in the spec
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:43): that have tests
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:43): ignoring cross dependencies
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:43): Which would be something like a normal code coverage metric
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:43): I would guess you'd want 100% of testable assertions to have tests
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:43): but then you have to sort out which MUSTs are relevant to the conformance class being tested, and which are in fact testable
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:44): The problem is that making such a metric turns out to be highly non-trivial on its own
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:44): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c did it for the 2D API spec, but it is non trivial to scale
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:45): http://philip.html5.org/tests/canvas/suite/tests/spec.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:47): Will we need to have two complete interoperable implementations of HTML5 validators too?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:48): well that is another interesting question - which conformance classes are relevant?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:49): Do we need two interoperable implementations of HTML authors?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:49): Because I have never seen two authors agree on correct usage :)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:50): "Web browsers and other interactive user agents" are an almost-superset of the requirements for many of the other conformance classes
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:50): conformance checkers are the only other class that is even plausibly testable
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:54): Are there *any* existing tests for conformance checkers?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:55): I'm sure I've seen some conformance tests for validator.nu

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:57): It seems hard to test the spec comprehensively when it doesn't distinguish between document conformance requirements that are mechanically verifiable and those that aren't
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:01): Is that something that needs interpretation, or just something that can be mechanically deduced from the conformance requirment?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (13:03): I don't think it can be deduced by machine which document conformance requirements are machine-testable
